Gong Li 'divorces Singaporean husband'

Gong Li, China's most famous actress, has reportedly divorced her Singaporean husband, igniting the hopes of Chinese fans that she may return to the mainland.

By Malcolm Moore in Shanghai

Published: 12:31PM BST 30 Jun 2010

Gong Li 'divorces Singaporean husband'

Gong Li starring in The Curse of the Golden Flower

Gong, 44, caused widespread dismay in China in 2008 when she renounced her Chinese citizenship and officially became Singaporean.

Neither country accepts dual nationality.

"I did it because of my family," she said recently in Shanghai. "No matter what people say, I am Chinese," she added. Nevertheless she was branded a "traitor" for leaving China.

The actress married Ooi Hoe Seong, the Singaporean former chief executive in Asia of British American Tobacco, in 1996 but the couple have rarely been seen in public and it is not known whether they have any children.

The Southern Metropolis Entertainment Weekly, a Chinese newspaper, said it had confirmed with Gong's agent, Zeng Jingchao, that the couple have now divorced.

"Actually, the marriage has only been nominal for a long time," said Xie Xiao, the editor, before speculating that Gong may have become romantically attached to John Cusack, her co-star in a recent film. Gong admitted recently that she always "stays in a hotel" during the time she spends in Singapore.

"The big question is: Will Gong Li become Chinese Chinese again?" said Shanghaiist.com, a local blog.

Gong shot to fame in a series of films directed by Zhang Yimou in the 1990s, including Red Sorghum and Raise the Red Lantern. She was heavily criticised, however, for ending Zhang's marriage with a subsequent affair.
